The common argument has long been that we need to change our practices to slow down climate change in order to save the planet. Though the sentiment is understandable, this however is a misleading argument. It's never been a case of saving the planet or not, the earth will endure, life will endure whether we continue our destructive practices or not. The real question has always been "do we, as human beings, wish to survive?" Because, yes, although the planet will be fine regardless, we might not be, nor will a plethora of lifeforms that are being adversely affected by our behaviour. We and many other lifeforms may not be here any longer if the planet becomes inhospitable to us. I find it useful to re-frame the question that way as it makes it less abstract.

Ultimately though, the elephant in the room remains capitalism. Even with changes in the way we consume and the influx of new forms of renewal technologies, it won't be enough. Capitalism is an unsustainable system in the long run, as you cannot have continued growth, more and more profit, production and consumption within a finite system. There will be a tipping point and either we will slowly adapt or change the system to meet our changing reality, or we will remain in denial and it will inevitably collapse under its own weight, be it through wars or revolutions, etc. This cannot continue forever. To continue living on this planet in the far future we will have to radically re-envision the way that our societies functions, the manner in which we produce and consume and how we treat ourselves as a whole. We will have to adapt to a new way of living, or simply cease to exist.

The above video, like a lot of climate change claims, is bullshit.
Assuming the world average of 3.1mm increase per year is maintained the oceans will rise 93mm or less that 4 inches.
The Pacific Ocean has risen by just 65mm or 2.5 inches in the last 100 years.
That measurement was determined from the world's oldest recording station at Fort Denison, Sydney Harbour which began recording mean sea level in 1886.
Sydney Harbour is a part of the Pacific Ocean.
The 100 year trend of 0.65mm/yr registered in Sydney Harbour, is below the world average of about 3.1mm/year.
It has been reported that Tuvalu, an island group in the South Pacific has lost islands due to sea level rise.
While it is true that they have lost some small islands, over the last four decades, there has been a net increase in land area of the islets of 73.5 ha or 181.6 acres.

Waterworld is a 1995 science fiction set a few hundred years in the future at a time when the polar ice caps have melted and the land areas of the world have been submerged under the oceans, a modern version of Noah's Flood. The film stars Kevin Kostner. When Director Reynolds quit, Kostner took on the job of directing the film.

I enjoyed this film because for the most part I was able to suspend disbelief in the science. Not everyone was able to do that.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) points out that, "The timeline for this event is rather vague: "probably more than 5,000 years, some scientists say".

Based on the volumes of land ice, the United States Geological Survey (USGS) estimated the potential sea level rise as 80 meters (about 260 feet). In my opinion, the estimate by the USGS is more reliable than that given by National Geographic.

How the Movie Begins

Waterworld opens to show a revolving globe with rising sea level. The opening shows the entire Continental US being submerged, including the Appalachian Mountains.

New York City

New York City is entirely submerged under the ocean and Costner has to dive deep into the sea to reach street level. So where is the Empire State Building?

The real Empire State Building stands on a site 15 meters above sea level, thus an 80 meter rise in sea level would reach 65 meters above ground level. The building has 102 floors from the ground to the roof and is 380 meters tall. That means Costner should have been able to enter a window on the 17th floor, which would be at sea level.

Do you understand that your model shows that melting ice will weaken the Atlantic Conveyor, but failts to account for if the Conveyor stops altogether. The Atlantic Conveyor has stopped in the past -- and it's happened when the salt to fresh ratio near Iceland became too high. Those sea-level rises DEPEND on everything staying static. But if the Atlantic Conveyor ends, which is closer and closer to happening, then not only will oceans stop rising, the ice caps will start to increase and we will enter a new Ice Age. The last this happened, when so much freshwater entered the ocean was when several meteors struck North America 12,800 years ago.

We know of at least two, possibly three strikes, possibly more. One hit central Manitoba, vaporizing billions of gallons of water trapped in the Laurentide Glacier (hence no crater), but the cores from the event show a meteor strike event. This massive event flooded the ocean and shut down the Atlantic Conveyor for 1200-1300 years. We entered the Younger Dryas. Meanwhile, Dr Anonio Zamora, a geophysicist, documents a second strike hitting the south part of Saginaw Bay. According to Zamora, the impact would have vaporized all like within a 1200 kilometer radius. There is a burn layer in the soil, that shows megafauna below that carbon layer, yet above, all the megafauna vanished.

Antonio Zamora narrates one impact site that white the south shore of Saginaw Bay, here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=npXY8mu2hhU

It is the collapse of the Atlantic Conveyor that will keep this massive flooding from happening. The excess moisture will descend as snow as we enter a new Ice Age.

Not to play devils advocate here, but yes while oceans rise and sea side land masses are submerged, at the same time other land masses that are currently uninhabitable or are very hard places to live such as the large majority of Siberia that has areas such as in Yakutsk, Russia that average Temps are around Minus 58F and can get as low as Minus 89F, then become more habitable for humans. So while the earth's climate is going to change, with or without human intervention, and some areas are lost, at the same time other areas are going to be gained. Who knows, one day humans may actually be living in Antarctica and the mountains ranges that are buried under miles of ice in the north pole will be visible and be the new summer home for some people. So while climate change due to human neglect IS scary, climate change in general is not ALL "Doom and Gloom". Cold parts of the earth become warm and warm parts become cold, this has been happening for as long as the Earth as existed for 4.5 Billion years, so why would we think it should stop now.

They're are so many more offsetting variables that the doomsdayers unwittingly, or maybe intentionally, fail to consider or postulate in their end of the world scenarios.

The body of water would cause cloud formation over the African interior, reflecting a lot of solar radiation at the equator, increasing rainfall to help with the water shortages and potentially spawning a new rain-forest.
It would take a lot of studies and research before starting and the only way to bankroll such an endeavor would be to enlist the help of the US military and/or Tesla, SpaceX and The boring company. In order to make it a fresh water lake to use as a reservoir, the most cost effective way would probably be to capture some of the burgs and fresh water sea ice from around Greenland and Antarctica and ship them in rather than trying to maintain a desalination and pumping station from the coast that could even begin to keep up with evaporation until the area was sufficiently cooled to be self sustaining.

Aren’t climate models a bit dicey though? I mean there are so many variables that we can’t actually account for them all. I mean, yes there is global warming and yes, the ecosystems of both ocean and land are being effected and yes, it’s our fault and yes, we need to get to zero emissions ASAP, but at the same time, these climate models are shaky to say the least. I mean based on the predictions made when I was younger, the oceans should have already risen around 20-30 feet, but that is way off from what actually happened. Perhaps our models are better now, but it’s still difficult to predict climate years in advance.

I don’t know, am I wrong about this? What assumptions do many of these models make? Do they have limitations? How sure can we really be about what they predict? And how does knowing all of this change anything? The fishing industry is massive and is on track to decimating the fish population and the ocean’s ecosystems. They do far more damage than climate change to the ocean and they’re responsible for almost half of the plastic in the ocean. So if you want to save ocean ecosystems, target the fishing industry. Here are some things I found, which you can incorporate into your daily life with little to no effort.

1. Switch your search engine to Ecosia. It's a search engine that plants trees in exchange for something you do everyday. It gives 80% of its profits to tree planting. It won't require anything on your behalf, just a simple switch.

2. Reduce milk and meat consumption. By simply reducing the amount of such products you consume, you could have a huge impact on the environment without an impact on your health. Instead of, say, eating meat 3 times a weak, try to bring it to 3 times a fortnight. By just this, you would offset carbon emission by a HUGE amount.

3. Take some action. Switch off that light in the kitchen. Turn off the tap while brushing. Simple, household saving, will also have an impact on the global Carbon emissions.

4. Reduce air travel. There are many places to visit in your own homestate. Instead of going somewhere exotic, give your closer cities a chance. Prefer car or train for the required travel.

5. Start taking public transport. The simplest way is to do this. Instead of needlessly traveling by car just to buy some small items, try using public transport or walking/cycling.


And remember the Butterfly Effect. Everything has an impact. It is up to you to make it a positive one.
